https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 23/590
(f) Nothing in this division shall bar a person who owns, operates or controls rental dwellings, whether
located on the same property or one or more contiguous parcels of property, from reserving any grouping of
dwellings for the rental or lease to tenants with a minor child or children; provided, however, in the event that
said reserved area is completely leased or rented, the person owning, operating or controlling said rental
dwelling may not refuse to rent or lease any other available dwelling to the prospective tenant on the basis of
the tenant's status as parent or any other of the protected classifications set forth in this division.
(1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-25; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.06; Ordinance 3189
adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.038 Unlawful intimidation
It shall be unlawful for any person to harass, threaten, harm, damage or otherwise penalize any individual,
group or business because he or they have complied with the provisions of this division, because he or they
have exercised his or their rights under this division or enjoyed the benefits of this division, or because he or
they have made a charge, testified or assisted in any manner in any investigation or in any proceeding
hereunder or have made any report to the administrator. (1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-30; Ordinance 297 adopted
12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.07; Ordinance 3189 adopted 6/4/1996)
Secs. 1.09.039–1.09.060 Reserved
Part II. Administration and Enforcement
Sec. 1.09.061 Fair housing administrator
The mayor shall appoint and the council shall confirm a fair housing administrator (hereinafter referred to as
“administrator”), who shall have the responsibility for implementing this division. The administrator may
delegate his authority to investigate and conciliate complaints to other city employees under his direction. (1972
Code, sec. 9-1/2-26; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.15; Ordinance 3189 adopted
6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.062 Filing of complaint
(a) Only the person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice [or] who believes
he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that has occurred or is occurring (hereinafter
referred to as “person aggrieved”) may file a complaint with the administrator. Such complaints shall be in
writing and shall identify the person alleged to have committed or alleged to be committing a discriminatory
housing practice and shall state the facts upon which the allegations of a discriminatory housing practice are
based. The administrator shall prepare complaint forms and furnish them without charge to any person, upon
request.
(b) A copy of all complaints filed with the city shall also be forwarded to the Fair Housing and Equal
Opportunity Division of the Region VI Office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
(c) The administrator shall provide for free administrative counseling to those complainants who wish to file a
private suit for relief in the local, state or federal court.
(d) If at any time the administrator shall receive or discover credible evidence and shall have probable cause
to believe that any person or persons have committed or are committing a discriminatory housing practice as to
which no complaint has been filed, the administrator may prepare and file a complaint upon his own motion and
in his own name and such complaint shall thereafter be treated in the same manner as a complaint filed by a
person aggrieved.
(e) The administrator shall receive and accept notification and referral complaints from the U.S. Attorney
General and the U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair
Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284, and shall treat such complaints hereunder in the same manner as
complaints filed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 24/590
(f) All complaints shall be filed within 60 days following the occurrence of an alleged discriminatory housing
practice. Upon the filing or referral of any complaint, the administrator shall provide notice of the complaint by
furnishing a copy of such complaint to the persons named therein who allegedly committed or were threatening
to commit an alleged discriminatory housing practice. The accused may file an answer to the complaint within
15 days of receipt of the written complaint.
(g) All complaints and answers shall be subscribed and sworn to before an officer authorized to administer
oaths.
(1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-27; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.16; Ordinance 3189
adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.063 Investigation of complaint
(a) Upon the filing or referral of a complaint as herein provided, the administrator shall cause to be made a
prompt and full investigation of the matter stated in the complaint.
(b) If the administrator determines that there is not probable cause to believe that a particular alleged
discriminatory housing practice has been committed, the administrator shall take no further action with respect
to that alleged offense.
(c) During or after the investigation, but subsequent to the mailing of the notice of complaint, the
administrator shall, if it appears that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is threatening to occur,
attempt by informal endeavors to effect conciliation, including voluntary discontinuance of the discriminatory
housing practice and adequate assurance of future voluntary compliance with the provisions of this division.
Nothing said or done in the course of such informal endeavors may be made public by the administrator, by the
complainant or by any other party to the proceedings without the written consent of all persons concerned.
(d) Upon completion of the investigation and informal endeavors at conciliation by the administrator, but
within 30 days of the filing of the complaint with the administrator, if the efforts of the administrator to secure
voluntary compliance have been unsuccessful, and if the administrator has made a determination that a
discriminatory housing practice has in fact occurred, the administrator shall recommend to the city attorney that
such violations be prosecuted in the municipal court. With such recommendations, the administrator shall refer
his entire file to the city attorney. The city attorney shall, within 30 days after such referral, make a
determination as to whether to proceed with prosecution of such complaint in the municipal court. If the city
attorney determines to prosecute, he shall institute a complaint and prosecute same to conclusion within 30
days after such determination or as soon thereafter as practicable.
(1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-28; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.17; Ordinance 3189
adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.064 Cooperation with federal officials
The administrator and the city attorney are authorized to cooperate with the U.S. Secretary of Housing and
Urban Development and the U.S. Attorney General pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair Housing Act of
1968, Public Law 90-284, and may render such service to the Secretary as they shall deem appropriate to
further the policies of this division. (1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-31; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code,
sec. 92.18; Ordinance 3189 adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.065 Education and public information
In order to further the objectives of this division, the administrator may conduct educational and public
information programs. (1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-32; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec. 92.19;
Ordinance 3189 adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.066 Cumulative legal effect
This division is cumulative in its legal effect and is not in lieu of any and all other legal remedies which the
person aggrieved may pursue. (1972 Code, sec. 9-1/2-29; Ordinance 297 adopted 12/4/1979; 1995 Code, sec.
92.20; Ordinance 3189 adopted 6/4/1996)
Sec. 1.09.067 Home investment partnership program marketing policies
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 25/590
(a) In accordance within the regulations of the HOME Investment Partnership Program and in furtherance of
the city's commitment to nondiscrimination and equal opportunity in housing, the city has established the
following procedures to affirmatively market its programs. These procedures are intended to further the
objectives of title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Fair Housing Amendments of 1988, and Executive
Order 11063.
(b) The city's policy is that individuals and families will not be discriminated against, in their housing choices
or in access of housing services, on the basis of race, color, sex, religion, disability, national origin or familial
status. The city is operating under all other applicable federal fair housing laws and other applicable federal,
state, and local housing laws.
(c) The city is committed to the goals of affirmative marketing, which will be implemented in the specific steps
outlined as follows:
(1) Inform the general public and potential applicants of this policy and other program information
through news releases, print ads, public meetings, flyers, and/or other means throughout the target
area served by the city.
(2) Discuss program guidelines and procedures and disperse applications via a public meeting.
(3) Post available information in public places, including application centers and area social
service agencies that work with minorities, disabled individuals, or other protected groups.
(4) Incorporate the Equal Housing Opportunity slogan in all program materials.
(5) Accommodate non-English speaking individuals residing in the community.
(6) Solicit applications from persons not likely to apply without special outreach through identified
minority organizations such as minority churches.
(7) Inform community leaders, housing owners, social service agencies, public and/or nonprofit
groups, lenders and realty groups, and other interested parties of meetings via public notices printed
in the area newspaper.
(8) Record complaints, if any, regarding unfair marketing practices and resolve by joint
consultation.
(9) The city will maintain records of demographic information of applicants for services. This
information is included on HUD and TDHCA set-up and close-out forms. Copies of advertisements,
brochures, flyers, and other program materials will be maintained in the program file. Dates, notices
and attendance records from public outreach meetings, if any, will also be maintained within the
program file.
(10) The city will assess its outreach and affirmative marketing efforts and report its results to
TDHCA at the close of the contract period. This will include a list of outreach methods, an
assessment of success or failure of these methods and corrective action to improve affirmative
marketing as necessary.
(1995 Code, sec. 92.21; Resolution 3469 adopted 5/23/2000; Resolution 3562 adopted 3/5/2002)
ARTICLE 1.10 LIBRARY*
Sec. 1.10.001 Library department established
A city library department is hereby established by the city council, which department shall be a part of the city
government. (1972 Code, sec. 2-71; Ordinance 2782 adopted 5/1/1990; 1995 Code, sec. 33.20)
Sec. 1.10.002 Failure to return library materials
(a) A person commits an offense if he intentionally or knowingly fails to return library materials to the Kurth
Memorial Library which were loaned to the member or borrowed in the member's name.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 26/590
(b) The member's intent and knowledge shall be presumed if:
(1) Pursuant to agreement, the library materials were to be returned on a date specified;
(2) Actual notice is given or notice in writing is sent by depositing in the United States mail the
notice addressed to the member at his address shown on the records of the library stating that the
library materials were not returned on the date specified; and
(3) The library material is not returned to the owner within 20 days of receipt of such notice.
(c) If notice is given in accordance with subsection (b)(2) of this section, it is presumed that the notice was
received no later than five days after it was sent.
(d) In prosecution under this section, it is no defense that the member, though the actual borrower, no longer
possesses the library materials.
(e) In prosecution under this section, it is an affirmative defense that another borrowed the library material in
the name of the member without his effective consent.
(1972 Code, sec. 15-6; Ordinance 350 adopted 4/1/1986; 1995 Code, sec. 130.02)
ARTICLE 1.11 PARKS AND RECREATION*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 1.11.001 Parks, recreation and open space master plan adopted
The Parks, Recreation and Open Space Master Plan attached as exhibit A to Resolution 4184 is hereby
approved and adopted and incorporated by reference as if set out in full herein. Future decisions of the city
regarding the development of the park system shall be made after consulting the master plan. (1995 Code, sec.
96.07; Resolution 4184 adopted 1/5/2010)
Sec. 1.11.002 Definitions
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
Park and lake. The Ellen Trout Memorial Park and the lake therein.
Zoo. The Ellen Trout Zoo.
(1972 Code, sec. 10-1; 1995 Code, sec. 96.01)
Sec. 1.11.003 Penalty
Any person guilty of violating a provision of this article for which no other penalty is provided shall be punished
by a fine of not more than $500.00. (1972 Code, sec. 22-75(b); Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; Ordinance
384 adopted 8/21/1990; 1995 Code, sec. 96.99(A))
Sec. 1.11.004 Certain areas of park reserved
There is hereby reserved from the land designated as the Ellen Trout Memorial Park those portions used in
connection with the pumping plant, overground storage tanks and the residences, house and grounds used by
the firemen of the city for recreational purposes. (Ordinance 948 adopted 7/16/1957; 1972 Code, sec. 10-2;
1995 Code, sec. 96.02)
Sec. 1.11.005 Reservation of rights by city
(a) The city council reserves the exclusive control and marketing of all timber, growing and standing, in the
Ellen Trout Memorial Park. Also, there is reserved the house and grounds on the north side of the lake used
and maintained by the firemen of the city. The city council retains the exclusive use and control of all residential
buildings, the pump house and all facilities used in connection with the water system of the city.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 27/590
(b) Should it ever become necessary for the city to use the water stored in the lake for municipal purposes,
the city reserves the right to cancel and discontinue all permits for fishing, boating and recreational purposes
granted or issued by the parks and recreation advisory board.
(Ordinance 948 adopted 7/16/1957; 1972 Code, sec. 10-3; 1995 Code, sec. 96.03; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 1.11.006 Jurisdiction of police; enforcement of rules
The Ellen Trout Lake and park area owned and operated by the city shall be under the jurisdiction of the police
department of the city, and all rules and regulations concerning such lake and park area shall be enforced by
the police department. (Ordinance 204 adopted 7/2/1963; 1972 Code, sec. 10-4; 1995 Code, sec. 96.04)
Sec. 1.11.007 Authority of city manager to promulgate rules
The city manager is hereby authorized to promulgate such rules as he deems necessary and essential in the
premises to regulate the recreational and lake facilities at the Ellen Trout Lake and park area, and such rules as
promulgated by him shall be binding on all persons using such lake and park area. (Ordinance 204 adopted
7/2/1963; 1972 Code, sec. 10-5; 1995 Code, sec. 96.05)
Sec. 1.11.008 Shooting prohibited; exception
There shall be no shooting in the park and on the lake except such shooting regulations as may be prescribed
by the city relative to the shooting of ducks during the duck season. (Ordinance 948 adopted 7/16/1957; 1972
Code, sec. 10-6; 1995 Code, sec. 96.06)
Sec. 1.11.009 Rental of Rock House and Brandon Center
The fee schedule and regulations for the Rock House at Chambers Park and the Brandon Center at Brandon
Park are set forth in the fee schedule. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Secs. 1.11.010–1.11.040 Reserved
Division 2. Conduct in Public Parks
Sec. 1.11.041 Definitions
For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
Director. The director of the parks and recreation of the city.
Park. A park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other area in the city, owned, used or
designated by the city, and devoted to active or passive recreation.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-70; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.15)
Sec. 1.11.042 Enforcement
(a) Generally. The director and park attendants shall, in connection with their duty imposed by law, diligently
enforce the provisions of this division.
(b) Ejection from park. The director and any park attendant shall have the authority to eject from the park any
person acting in violation of this division.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-77; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.22)
Sec. 1.11.043 Hours; closed areas
(a) Hours. Except for unusual or unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be open to the public every day of the
year during the hours as posted.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 28/590
(b) Closed areas. Any section or any part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the director at
any time for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-76; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.21)
Sec. 1.11.044 Damaging park property; interference with city programs
No person in a park shall:
(1) Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace or remove any building, bridge,
table, bench, fireplace, railing, paving or paving material, water line or other public utilities or parts or
appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments,
stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property
or appurtenances, either real or personal.
(2) Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition.
(3) Dig or remove any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs, plants or other wood or materials, or make
any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting or other means or agency.
(4) Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark or pick the
flowers or seeds of any tree or plant.
(5) Dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty
or usefulness of the area.
(6) Willfully interfere with, disrupt or prevent the orderly conduct of any supervised play or
amusement program being conducted by the city.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-71; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.16)
Sec. 1.11.045 Depositing trash; polluting water
No person in a park shall throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any
fountain, pond, lake, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters any substance, matter or thing,
liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of the water, or dump, deposit or leave any bottles,
broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse or any other trash in any such
waters or on the grounds of any park. (1972 Code, sec. 22-72; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code,
sec. 96.17)
Sec. 1.11.046 Traffic regulations
No person in a park shall:
(1) Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the state motor vehicle traffic laws in regard to
the equipment and operation of motorized vehicles, together with such regulations as are contained
in this division or other ordinances.
(2) Fail to obey all traffic officers and park employees, such persons being hereby authorized and
instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets
or roads immediately adjacent thereto.
(3) Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking
and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property.
(4) Operate or drive any motorized vehicle at a speed in excess of 20 miles per hour, except upon
such roads as are posted and designated for a greater speed.
(5) Park a vehicle in other than an established or designated parking area, and such use shall be
in accordance with the posted directions thereat and with the instructions of any attendant who may
be present.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 29/590
(6) Double park any vehicle on any road or parkway unless directed by park officials, or in any
manner block any roadway within a park.
(7) Drive any motorized vehicle, including motorcycles, on any area except the paved park roads,
parking areas or other areas designated for such traffic.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-73; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.18)
Sec. 1.11.047 Recreational activities
No person in a park shall:
(1) Swim, bathe or wade in any waters or waterways in or adjacent to any park, except in such
waters and at such places as are provided therefor, and in compliance with such regulations as are
herein set forth or may hereafter be adopted.
(2) Frequent any waters or places designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or
congregate thereat, except between such hours of the day as shall be designated by the director for
such purposes for each individual area.
(3) Appear in a bathing suit that will indecently expose his person.
(4) Dress or undress except in bathing houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose.
(5) Bring into, commence or operate any boat or other watercraft, whether motor-powered or not,
upon any waters, except at places designated by the director.
(6) Fish in any waters, except in waters designated by the director for that use and under such
regulations and restrictions as have been or may be prescribed by the director.
(7) Hunt, trap or pursue wildlife at any time. No person shall use, carry or possess firearms of any
description or any air rifles, spring guns, bows and arrows, slings or any other form of weapon
potentially harmful to wildlife and dangerous to human safety.
(8) Picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for that purpose.
(9) Camp in any area except at places designated for camping by the director.
(10) Ride a bicycle on other than a paved vehicular road or path designated for that purpose and
ride a bicycle other than on the right-hand side of the road paving as close as conditions permit. A
bicyclist shall at all times operate his machine with reasonable regard to the safety of others, signal
all turns, pass to the right of any vehicle he is overtaking and pass to the right of any vehicle he may
be meeting.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-74; Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; 1995 Code, sec. 96.19)
Sec. 1.11.048 Behavior
No person in a park shall:
(1) Possess alcoholic beverages, nor shall any person drink alcoholic beverages at any time in
the park.
(2) Remain in the park if he is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs.
(3) Discharge, set off or otherwise cause to explode or discharge or burn any firecrackers,
torpedo, rocket or any other fireworks or explosives of inflammable material except at a citysponsored
event.
(4) Build or attempt to build a fire except in such areas and under such regulations as may be
designated by the director.
(5) Gamble or participate in or abet any game of chance.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 30/590
(6) Sleep, camp out, or inhabit any area, except at a city-sponsored event.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-75(a); Ordinance 266 adopted 5/21/1974; Ordinance 384 adopted 8/21/1990; 1995 Code,
sec. 96.20; Ordinance 432 adopted 2/21/2012; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 1.11.049 Smoking prohibited
(a) Prohibition. A person shall not smoke or possess a burning tobacco product within the boundaries of any
city park.
(b) Definition. For purposes of this section, “smoke” means to emit or exhale the smoke of burning tobacco,
weed or other plant or tobacco product.
(c) Posting of signs. The city manager shall cause conspicuous signage to be posted at entrances and at
other common areas where people gather within city parks. Each sign shall state “Smoking Strictly Prohibited
Per City Ordinance No. 4133.”
(1995 Code, sec. 96.23; Ordinance 4133 adopted 4/21/2009)

Division 3. Ellen Trout Lake*
Sec. 1.11.081 Swimming prohibited
Swimming or bathing in the lake is hereby prohibited, and it shall be unlawful for any person to bathe therein.
(Ordinance 948 adopted 7/16/1957; Ordinance 204 adopted 7/2/1963; 1972 Code, sec. 10-17; 1995 Code, sec.
96.30)
Sec. 1.11.082 Water skiing prohibited
Unauthorized water skiing on Ellen Trout Lake shall be prohibited, and any person water skiing, or engaging in
the sport of water skiing, on such lake shall be deemed guilty of an offense. (Ordinance 204 adopted 7/2/1963;
1972 Code, sec. 10-18; 1995 Code, sec. 96.31)
Sec. 1.11.083 Use of motor-propelled boats
The use and operation of motor-propelled boats in Ellen Trout Lake is prohibited except upon specific approval
of the city council. (1972 Code, sec. 10-19; Ordinance 249 adopted 4/4/1972; 1995 Code, sec. 96.32)

Division 4. Ellen Trout Zoo
Sec. 1.11.121 Entering or remaining on grounds during hours closed to public
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter onto or upon the zoo grounds, for any purpose, at any time other
than during those times during which the zoo is open to the public. This provision shall not apply to properly
authorized zoo personnel or other authorized service or construction personnel. (Ordinance 238 adopted
2/16/1971; 1972 Code, sec. 10-29; 1995 Code, sec. 96.40)
Sec. 1.11.122 Bringing animals onto grounds
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any animal onto or upon the zoo grounds, except by permission from
the zoo director. (Ordinance 238 adopted 2/16/1971; 1972 Code, sec. 10-30; 1995 Code, sec. 96.41)
Sec. 1.11.123 Walking, standing or sitting on fences or other fixtures
It shall be unlawful for any person to walk, stand, sit upon or cross over any border, flowerbed, monument,
vase, fountain, railing, fence or other physical barrier in the zoo. (Ordinance 238 adopted 2/16/1971; 1972
Code, sec. 10-32; 1995 Code, sec. 96.43)

Sec. 1.11.124 Placing objects in area where animal is confined
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, roll, shove, push or in any other way cause the entrance into an
area of animal confinement or keeping in the zoo, any stone, ball or other physical object, other than special
animal food. (Ordinance 238 adopted 2/16/1971; 1972 Code, sec. 10-31; 1995 Code, sec. 96.42)
Sec. 1.11.125 Teasing or annoying animals
It shall be unlawful to tease, annoy, molest, catch, injure, kill, or throw any stone, object or missile of any kind

It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any area wherein an animal or animals are being confined or

prohibiting the feeding of animals, it shall be unlawful for any person to feed animals anything other than
peanuts, popcorn, bread, or foodstuffs sold by the zoo concessionaire which are labeled specifically for the
purpose of feeding the animals. (Ordinance 238 adopted 2/16/1971; 1972 Code, sec. 10-36; 1995 Code, sec.

Division 5. Kurth Lake*
Sec. 1.11.161 Penalty
A violation of any provision of this division shall be deemed a class C misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. (1995 Code, sec. 96.99(B); Ordinance 4305
adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.162 Applicability
This division applies to all waters impounded by Kurth Lake Dam constituting Kurth Lake and their tributaries
and the adjacent lands owned or controlled by the city, herein referred to as “the lake.” (1995 Code, sec. 96.60;
Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.163 Assumption of risk
The city shall not be liable to any person on account of the loss or damage of any property that may be placed
in or upon the lake, nor shall the city be liable to any person whomsoever on account of personal injuries or loss
of life that may be sustained by any person in or upon the lake. Any person entering in or upon the lake shall do
so at his or her sole risk and shall not be privileged to enter or remain in or upon such lake save and except
under the terms of this division that have been or may be adopted by the city council, nor shall the city be
responsible or liable in such instances as set out in this section. (1995 Code, sec. 96.61; Ordinance 4305
adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.164 Enforcement; registration of watercraft; unsafe watercraft
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 32/590
(a) The city manager or his or her designee shall be in charge of lake operations and the enforcement of the
regulations herein adopted. Any peace officer shall keep the peace and patrol the lake in order to enforce this
division and all other laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the city or state relating to the waters of the lake
and [is authorized] to make arrests or write tickets for any violation of this division, other city ordinance, or state
law and/or to exclude any person found violating this division or state law from the lake.
(b) All boats and other watercraft, before the boats and watercraft are permitted to be placed on the lake,
shall be registered with the state and conform to Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code, title 4, Water Safety, and any
other applicable state statute and/or city ordinances. If it is concluded the watercraft or boat is unsafe or
dangerous to life, such watercraft may be removed from the lake.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.62; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.165 Waiver of regulations
The city manager may, upon application and after a hearing, waive for a specified length of time such of the
terms, provisions, and conditions of this division that may be deemed appropriate for the accommodation of
educational purposes and other special events as may be permitted from time to time, and subject to such
safety measures as the city manager may require. (1995 Code, sec. 96.63; Ordinance 4305 adopted
12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.166 Commercial activities; organized recreational activities or events
(a) It is unlawful for any person to engage in any commercial activity on the lake.
(b) No person shall rent or let for hire boats on the lake.
(c) The city manager or his or her designee may authorize commercial or organized recreational activities or
events upon proper request. Activities or events for which authorization is required include fishing tournaments,
bird watching, or other related events. Requirements for authorization include:
(1) Assurances of financial responsibility, including appropriate insurance; and
(2) Signing an indemnification agreement with the city assuming responsibly for all damages or
claims arising out of the activity. The authorization shall specify where and under what conditions the
activity may be conducted to prevent the activity from adversely impacting use of the lake by the
general public.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.64; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.167 Maintenance of roads; damage to roads
All main roads around the lake are maintained by the city or other appropriate entity. Any damage to roadways
by private or corporate users shall be repaired by the city and billed to the private or corporate users based on
actual cost to the city. (1995 Code, sec. 96.65; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.168 Prohibited activities in water transfer channel
It is unlawful for any person to fish or swim in the concrete channel or to stop or moor a boat or watercraft on or
through the channel. (1995 Code, sec. 96.66; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.169 Prohibited activities near outlet structure and morning glory structure
It is unlawful to operate any boat or watercraft within the buoys at the morning glory structure and within 100
foot of the outlet structure. (1995 Code, sec. 96.67; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.170 Prohibited activities near intake structure
It is unlawful for any person except authorized repair or maintenance personnel to approach or fish from the
water intake structure or within 100 feet. (1995 Code, sec. 96.68; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.171 Camping
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 33/590
No person will be allowed to camp on the lake or on adjacent city-owned property. (1995 Code, sec. 96.69;
Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.172 Swimming
Swimming is not allowed on Kurth Lake or any adjacent waters on or accessed from city-owned property. (1995
Code, sec. 96.70; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.173 Parking of motor vehicles
It is unlawful for any person to leave unattended any motor vehicle with a boat trailer in tow within 50 feet of the
water of the lake unless in an area officially designated for public parking, and it is unlawful to park vehicles in
any designated safety or turn-around zone except as necessary while loading or unloading a boat. (1995 Code,
sec. 96.71; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.174 Signs and markers
(a) Placement. City personnel shall place signs and markers on the lake to mark and specify restricted areas
and for informational purposes.
(b) Damaging sign or marker. It is unlawful for any person to deface or otherwise damage any sign or marker
placed by the city on the lake.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.72; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.175 Domesticated animals and livestock prohibited
All domesticated animals are prohibited from the lake. It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any
livestock on city property. (1995 Code, sec. 96.73; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.176 Cutting vegetation; disturbing soil; dredging; artificial shelters or baited areas
(a) Cutting trees or brush. It is unlawful for any person to cut any trees or brush on any city-owned property
at the lake without the approval of the city engineer.
(b) Disturbing sod or removing soil. Sodding may not be disturbed unnecessarily. Soil may not be removed
nor the natural contour disturbed in any way on city-owned property without permission of the city engineer.
(c) Dredging. All dredging will be accomplished in accordance with U.S. Corps of Engineers rules and
guidelines, with approval of the Corps as applicable, and with approval of the city engineer.
(d) Artificial shelters or baited areas. No artificial shelters, such as willow tops, etc., or any baited area of any
kind shall be placed or allowed in the waters of the lake.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.74; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.177 Depositing trash
It is unlawful for any person to dump trash, brush, or garbage of any kind except in places designated by the
city. Trash receptacles located in parks, on benches, and at boat ramps are for facility users only, and no
household garbage may be deposited in these containers. (1995 Code, sec. 96.75; Ordinance 4305 adopted
12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.178 Ingress and egress across city land from privately owned land
Ingress and egress across city-owned land from privately owned land to a lake road or public road is prohibited
except by formal written approval by the city engineer. (1995 Code, sec. 96.76; Ordinance 4305 adopted
12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.179 Barrels, pontoons or other flotation devices
It is unlawful for any person to place barrels, pontoons, or other such containers upon or in the water of the
lake. The city may employ such devices for markers or other similar uses. (1995 Code, sec. 96.77; Ordinance
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 34/590
4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.180 Operation of boat while intoxicated
Any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates or any person who is
a habitual user of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates shall not operate or occupy or be in physical
control of any boat or other watercraft on the lake, nor shall the owner of any boat or other watercraft or any
person in charge or in control authorize or knowingly permit the boat or watercraft to be operated by any person
who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates. (1995 Code, sec. 96.78;
Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.181 Duties of operator of boat involved in accident
If the operator of any boat or watercraft [is] involved in an accident on the lake resulting in injury or death to any
person or in damage to property, he or she shall, so far as he or she can do so without danger to his or her own
vessel or passengers, if any, render aid to other persons affected by the collision and such assistance as may
be practicable and give his or her name, address, full identification of his or her boat and the name and address
of the owner of the boat struck or the operator or occupants of the boats collided with and shall report such
accident immediately to the city police department or the state parks and wildlife department. (1995 Code, sec.
96.79; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.182 Boats and boating generally; abandoned watercraft
(a) Safe operation of boats.
(1) Every operator of a boat or other watercraft on the lake shall at all times navigate the boat or
watercraft in a careful and prudent manner and at such rate of speed as not to endanger the life,
limb, or property of any person. The maximum speed limit on the lake is 35 mph.
(2) Boat operators in areas within 100 feet of a public boat ramp, intake or outlet structures, or
along the dam, whether designated by marker buoys or not, shall limit their motorboats to a no-wake
speed (five mph or less).
(b) Anchoring at sign, buoy or other marker; leaving boat unattended.
(1) It is unlawful for any boat to anchor or tie up to any posted sign, buoy, or other marker on the
water of the lake except in case of emergency.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to leave a boat unattended on the waters of the lake unless in
cases of emergency.
(c) Obstruction of ramp.
(1) It is unlawful for any person to block any public boat launch leading to the water of the lake.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to anchor a boat or other watercraft for fishing or other purposes
on the lake in such a position as to obstruct the entrance or exit to the public boat launch.
(d) Removal of unsafe craft from lake. The city, through the city manager or his or her designee, may require
the removal of any boat or other watercraft from the lake if it is deemed a navigational hazard or is in an unsafe
operating condition. In the event of noncompliance by the owner to such order, the craft will be removed from
the lake by the city and the owner will be assessed all costs.
(e) Overloading. No person owning or operating a boat or other watercraft on the lake may permit it to be
occupied by more persons than the rated capacity of such boat or other watercraft, [or] to be loaded with
passengers or cargo beyond its safe capacity, taking into consideration weather and other operating conditions.
(f) Standing in motorboat; riding on certain places.
(1) No person operating a motorboat on the lake may allow any person to ride or sit on the
gunwales (side rails) thereof or on the decking over the bow of the craft while underway, nor allow
any person to stand in such craft while underway.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 35/590
(2) Passengers or other persons aboard a motorboat may stand on the decking over the bow of
the boat to moor the boat or to cast off for any other necessary purpose.
(g) Operation of boats at night prohibited. No boat shall be operated on the lake between sunset and sunrise.
A boat may be operated between sunset and sunrise only as a result of mechanical failure or rescue
operations, and the lights required by the state Water Safety Act shall be operating and lighted regardless of the
size of the boat or motor.
(h) Fire extinguishers. Fire extinguishers are required in all boats as prescribed by the state Water Safety
Act, Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code, section 31.067.
(i) Abandoned boats and watercraft.
(1) Any boat or watercraft which is found upon the waters of the lake or upon any public property
immediately adjacent thereto and which is inoperable and left unattended for more than 24 hours, or
is unseaworthy and cannot be used as a safe means of transportation on the water, or that has
remained on the lake illegally for more than 24 hours, is deemed to be an abandoned watercraft. For
purposes of this section, “watercraft” shall include any motorboat, outboard motor, or vessel subject
to registration under state law.
(2) The city manager or his or her designee may authorize taking into custody any abandoned
watercraft found upon the water of, or on any public property immediately adjacent to, the lake. Any
watercraft deemed a navigational hazard may be removed from the lake.
(3) When any abandoned watercraft is taken into custody under the authority of these rules, the
city shall promptly notify by certified mail, return receipt requested, the last known registered owner
and all lienholders of record that the watercraft has been taken into custody. The notice shall
describe the watercraft by size, color, and general description and shall set forth the location of the
facility where the watercraft is being held, and shall further inform the owner and any lienholder of
the right to reclaim the watercraft within 30 days after the date of notice upon payment of all towing,
preservation and storage charges resulting from placing the watercraft in custody and upon paying
the required registration and fees as may be required by these rules. The notice shall further state
that the failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise the right to reclaim the watercraft within the
time provided shall be deemed a waiver of all right, title and interest in the watercraft and their
consent to the sale of the abandoned watercraft at a public auction, or to the removal and
destruction of the abandoned watercraft at a public auction.
(4) If the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined, or the registration contains no
address for the owner, or if it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and
addresses of all lienholders, notice by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation within
the city shall be sufficient to meet all requirements of notice pursuant to these rules. Such notice by
publication may contain a multiple listing of abandoned watercraft. Any such notice shall be within
the same time requirements and shall have the same contents required for a notice by certified mail.
(5) If an abandoned watercraft has not been reclaimed by the owner or lienholders as provided for
herein, the city shall sell the abandoned watercraft at a public auction or remove and destroy the
abandoned watercraft if deemed a navigational hazard. Sale of the abandoned watercraft must be
preceded by a notice in a newspaper of general circulation within the city or on the internet at least
three weeks before the sale takes place. The notice shall include the place and date of sale, a full
description of the watercraft to be sold, and the name of the owner, if known. The purchaser of the
watercraft shall take title to the watercraft free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership, shall
receive a sales receipt from the city and shall be entitled to register the purchased watercraft as
provided for herein. From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned watercraft, the city shall
reimburse itself for the expenses of the auction, towing, preserving, watercraft storage, notice and
publication costs which resulted from placing the abandoned watercraft in custody. Any remainder
from the proceeds of a sale shall be deposited in the city water and sewer fund for lake operations.
(6) If there are no purchasers of the watercraft at a public auction held pursuant to these rules, the
city can dispose of the watercraft as deemed appropriate.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.80; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 36/590
State law references–Water Safety Act, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code, ch. 31; abandoned motor vehicles, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code, ch. 683.
Sec. 1.11.183 Fishing
(a) Commercial fishing prohibited.
(1) No person may engage in commercial fishing on the lake.
(2) No person may use or operate a boat of any kind or description on the waters of the lake for
the purpose of catching and taking fish or game for market or sale.
(b) Hazardous floats. It is unlawful for any person to attach any glass, metal, or other solid floating objects
hazardous to boats to any trotline or gang hook set out in the waters of the lake. Flexible plastic bottles or foam
floats are not deemed to be a hazard to boats.
(c) Use of metal line or cable prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to place or extend any metal line or
cable in, over, on, or across the water of the lake.
(d) Trotlines and similar apparatus; nets prohibited.
(1) It is unlawful for any person to secure a trotline to any sign or buoy, or any part thereof, used
for designating a shallow water area or any restricted area of the lake or intake structure.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to set out any trotline or other similar apparatus at any time in the
lake and leave the same unattended for a period of time in excess of 24 hours.
(3) Name and contact information will be on trotlines or other similar apparatus.
(4) Any trotline or similar apparatus set out or left on in the waters of the lake in violation of this
division is hereby declared to be a nuisance, endangering the health, safety, and welfare of the
general public, and may be removed by any law enforcement officer or representative of the city
engineer's office.
(5) Nets are not allowed.
(e) Permit. A permit, purchased from the city, is required for fishing on the lake. The permit must be displayed
on or in a vehicle at all times while on city property adjacent to the lake. The permit must be readily visible from
the outside of the vehicle. Failure to display a permit may lead to penalties as allowed by this article, removal of
fishing privileges, and/or towing of the vehicle.
(1995 Code, sec. 96.81; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.184 Weapons; hunting
It is unlawful for a person to shoot, discharge, or hunt with a bow, crossbow, slingshot, gun, firearm, or any
other of weapon in, on, over, across, or upon the lake, except as it may be authorized by the city manager or
his or her designee. Any exception will be in writing from the city manager's office. (1995 Code, sec. 96.82;
Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.185 Restricted areas
(a) Dam and intake structure.
(1) No unauthorized person shall be permitted upon the dam for any purpose.
(2) No unauthorized person shall be permitted upon the intake structure for any purpose.
(3) No unauthorized person shall be permitted upon any pump station or intake structure.
(b) Other restricted areas. No person shall engage in any activity on the lake or around the lake in an area
which has been designated by the city as a restricted area and which has been plainly marked with signs that
such is a restricted area.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 37/590
(1995 Code, sec. 96.83; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010)
Sec. 1.11.186 Fees
Fees will be set by the council on a yearly basis. (1995 Code, sec. 96.84; Ordinance 4305 adopted 12/21/2010;
Ordinance adopting Code)
ARTICLE 1.12 TREES AND SHRUBS
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 1.12.001 Definitions
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
Park trees. Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and
all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park.
Plant. Any hedge, bush, shrub, vine, palm or other vegetation, except trees.
Property line. The boundary line of any street, which line marks the division between the street area and the
property abutting upon same.
Street trees. Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on
either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city.
(Ordinance 193 adopted 8/15/1961; 1972 Code, sec. 22-18; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec.
98.01)
Sec. 1.12.002 Penalty
Any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation, or agent or employee thereof, who shall violate any of
the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof in the municipal court
of the city shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00. (1972 Code, sec. 22-36; Ordinance 332 adopted
7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.99)
Sec. 1.12.003 Delegation of authority by city manager
The city manager is hereby expressly granted the authority to delegate any responsibility designated to his
office hereunder to any employee or department within the city, and the action of such employee or department
so designated shall constitute the action required of the office of the city manager as provided for hereunder.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-35; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.14)
Sec. 1.12.004 Interference with tree board
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents,
while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street
trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this article. (1972 Code, sec. 22-33; Ordinance
332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.12)
Sec. 1.12.005 Pruning or removal of trees dangerous to public safety
The city shall have the right to prune the branches of trees so that such branches shall not obstruct the light
from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of
14 feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. The owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous
trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the
right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the
street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic-control device or sign. (1972 Code, sec. 22-30;
Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.09; Ordinance 3738 adopted 2/15/2005)
Sec. 1.12.006 Removal of dead or diseased trees on private property
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 38/590
The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the
city when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a
potential threat to other trees within the city. The city tree board will notify in writing the owners of such trees.
Removal shall be done by the owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of notice. In
the event of failure of the owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove
such tree or trees, with the cost to be charged to the owner. If the owner fails to pay for the cost of removal, the
charge shall be impressed on the property of the owner as a lien. (1972 Code, sec. 22-31; Ordinance 332
adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.10; Ordinance 3405 adopted 9/7/1999)
Sec. 1.12.007 Plants taller than three feet prohibited near street corner
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed any plant having a height greater than three
feet above the level of the center of the nearest abutting street, on or in that portion of any corner lot in the city,
which portion is included in a triangle on the street corner of the lot formed by a diagonal line intersecting the
property lines at points 20 feet from the street corner intersection of the property lines. (Ordinance 193 adopted
8/15/1961; 1972 Code, sec. 22-37; 1995 Code, sec. 98.15)
Sec. 1.12.008 Trees and plants in sidewalk areas
(a) Plants taller than three feet prohibited near street corner. It shall be unlawful for either the owner or the
occupant of any corner lot in the city to place, maintain or permit or cause to be placed or maintained any plant
having a height greater than three feet above the level of the center of the nearest abutting street on or in that
area which lies between the property lines of such corner lot and the curblines of streets abutting such property
lines and which area extends for a distance of 50 feet back from the intersection of the curblines of such
abutting streets.
(b) Trees or plants obstructing passage. It shall be unlawful for either the owner or the occupant of any lot in
the city to place, maintain or permit or cause to be placed or maintained any tree or plant on or in the area
between the property line thereof and the curbline of any street abutting such property line, in such a way as to
obstruct the free passage on and use of that area by the public.
(c) Clearance of tree limbs. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property in the city to
maintain or permit limbs of trees growing thereon to overhang or grow above the area between his property line
and the curbline of any abutting street unless such limbs and all branches and foliage thereon are kept trimmed
and pruned to a minimum clearance of eight feet above the street level at the nearest curbline.
(d) Correction of violations. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause a written notice to be served
upon the owner or occupant of any property upon which any violation of subsections (a) through (c) of this
section exists to correct such condition as constitutes a violation of these subsections within ten days after
serving such notice. If such condition is not corrected or remedied or caused to be corrected or remedied by
such person by the end of such ten days' notice, the city manager is hereby authorized and directed to cause
the tree or plant or part thereof constituting such violation to be so trimmed, pruned or removed as to eliminate
the prohibited condition.
(Ordinance 193 adopted 8/15/1961; 1972 Code, secs. 22-37.1–22-37.4; 1995 Code, secs. 98-16–98.19)
Secs. 1.12.009–1.12.040 Reserved
Division 2. Trees and Shrubs on Public Property
Sec. 1.12.041 Approved street tree species
The following list constitutes the official street tree species for the city. The following shall be the suggested
varieties:
(1) Small trees.
(A) Crape myrtle;
(B) Flowering crabapple;

Sec. 1.12.042 Spacing of street trees
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 40/590
The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 1.12.041
of this article, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following, except in special plantings
designed or approved by a landscape architect:
(1) Small trees, 30 feet;
(2) Medium trees, 40 feet; and
(3) Large trees, 50 feet.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-24; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.03)
Sec. 1.12.043 Distance of street trees from curb and sidewalk
The distance trees may be planted from the curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the
three species size classes listed in section 1.12.041 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer to any
curb or sidewalk than the following:
(1) Small trees, three feet;
(2) Medium trees, five feet; and
(3) Large trees, seven feet.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-25; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.04; Ordinance 3738 adopted
2/15/2005)
Sec. 1.12.044 Distance of street trees from street corners and fireplugs
No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet to any street corner, measured from the point of the nearest
intersecting curbs or curblines, except as recommended by the tree board in downtown areas, with approval by
local and state street and highway agencies. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet to any fireplug.
(1972 Code, sec. 22-26; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.05; Ordinance 3738 adopted
2/15/2005)
Sec. 1.12.045 Distance of street trees from utility lines
No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 1.12.041 of this article may be planted
under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground
water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. (1972 Code, sec. 22-27; Ordinance 332 adopted
7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.06)
Sec. 1.12.046 Care, maintenance and removal
The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants, and shrubs within the lines of all
streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to
preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city tree board may remove, or
cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its
nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is
affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees
by adjacent property owners, providing that the selection and location of the trees is in accordance with section
1.12.041. (1972 Code, sec. 22-28; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code, sec. 98.07)
Sec. 1.12.047 Tree topping
It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree,
or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three
inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure
the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other
obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this article at the
determination of the city tree board. (1972 Code, sec. 22-29; Ordinance 332 adopted 7/3/1984; 1995 Code,
sec. 98.08)
