CHAPTER 13
UTILITIES
ARTICLE 13.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
(Reserved)
ARTICLE 13.02 SOLID WASTE†
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.02.001 Definitions
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
City. The City of Lufkin or the city solid waste services department.
Construction debris. All debris and waste materials resulting from building construction and/or repairs to any
premises, including, but not limited to, such items as scrap lumber, wallboard or sheetrock, wire, roofing
materials, carpet and padding.
Garbage. Putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from holding [handling], preparation, cooking or
consumption of food. Also, any other deleterious, putrescible or nonputrescible substance commonly
understood to be garbage.
Junk. Anything discarded by citizens and business that requires a special pickup service as per these
provisions. Items may include, but are not limited to, all white goods (appliances such as refrigerators, washers,
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 372/590
and the like) and furniture (mattresses, tables, and the like).
Other curbside collection. Service requiring picking up and disposing of discarded items not serviced under
normal collection procedures outlined in these provisions.
Recyclable. Any item that is diverted from the landfill and placed through another cycle to make new (aluminum
cans, steel cans, plastics #1 and #2, cardboard, newspaper, office paper, magazines and junk mail).
Refuse. All putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste (except body waste), including garbage, rubbish, ashes,
and the like.
White goods. Appliances placed for special pickups. Items such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, dishwashers,
water heaters, and air conditioning and heating units are examples.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-1; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.01; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.002 Penalties
(a) Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this article for which another penalty is not
specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding $2,000.00 and/or discontinuation
of service. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or
continues.
(b) Any commercial garbage vehicle traveling on the city streets that violates the provisions of section
13.02.009 shall be subject to a fine of up to $2,000.00 for each offense or a discontinuation of service.
(c) Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of divisions 1 through 4 of this article will be guilty
of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of up to $2,000.00 upon conviction. Each day during or upon which the
person shall violate or continue violation of any provision of these sections or noncompliance with any
requirement of these sections shall constitute a distinct and separate offense.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-33; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.99; Ordinance 3556 adopted
1/15/2002; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.003 Collection service to be provided by city
The city's solid waste services department shall be the exclusive provider of residential and commercial
garbage, rubbish, recyclable refuse and other collection and disposal services for all premises within the city,
and it shall be unlawful for any other person to provide residential or commercial garbage, rubbish or refuse
collection or disposal services to any person for compensation within the city, or to make use of the public
streets for that purpose, without prior approval of the city's solid waste services department. (1995 Code, sec.
50.02; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.004 Containers required; accumulations of refuse
No owner, lessee or occupant of any public or private property shall permit to accumulate upon his premises
any refuse, except in approved containers. (1972 Code, sec. 13-2; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995
Code, sec. 50.03; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.005 Unauthorized use of city service
(a) A person commits an offense if he places, or permits another to place, refuse from outside the city limits
at any location with the intent for refuse to be collected by the city service.
(b) A person commits an offense if he places, or causes to be placed, any refuse in any location for use by
other persons, firms or corporations to whom a service fee is charged.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-3; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005; 1995 Code,
sec. 50.04(A), (B))
Sec. 13.02.006 Removing material placed in city-owned container
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 373/590
No person other than the current resident of the property obtaining such container, a city collector or an
authorized city employee shall remove, pick up or transfer material which has been placed in a city-owned
container at any residence or business. Each violation of this provision which occurs from one or more
collection locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as provided in section 13.02.002.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-3; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005; 1995 Code,
sec. 50.04(C))
Sec. 13.02.007 Permissible and non-permissible refuse
(a) The city shall collect all refuse commonly understood to be household waste, placed in plastic garbage
bags. Bags shall be placed in approved containers provided by the city.
(b) The city shall not collect any bricks, concrete, concrete blocks, dirt, rocks, or other earthen materials, car
parts, large metal objects or any other construction materials, such as, but not limited to, boards, sheetrock,
carpet, and the like (see definition for “construction debris” in section 13.02.001).
(c) All permissible refuse shall be placed in approved containers.
(d) Any boxes or cardboard shall be broken down and placed in provided recycling containers for collection.
(e) Tires will not be collected.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-4; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.05; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.008 Collection regulations
The city manager or his appointee shall have the authority to make regulations concerning days of collection,
types and location of waste containers and collection, and conveyance as he shall find necessary, provided that
such regulations are not contrary to the provisions hereof. (1972 Code, sec. 13-10; Ordinance 2933 adopted
2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.06; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.009 Collection vehicles to be covered
(a) All garbage vehicles used for the collection and transportation of garbage and refuse shall be covered
with a net, canvas or wire mesh, adequate to prevent the contents from falling or blowing into public streets or
adjacent property.
(b) The mesh shall be of a size and shape that has an opening no greater than one-half inch square and
shall be installed and maintained at all times adequate to prevent any garbage from falling or blowing off the
vehicle.
(1995 Code, sec. 50.07; Ordinance 3556 adopted 1/15/2002; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.010 Disposal of construction and demolition debris
Construction and demolition debris shall be removed at the responsibility of the owner. All debris shall be
properly disposed of according to guidelines established by the state commission on environmental quality. The
city is the exclusive hauler within the city. An owner or his contractor who has the proper equipment and
conducted the demolition, construction or clearance may dispose of the resulting debris generated from work
on that owner's property. (1995 Code, sec. 50.50; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)

Division 3. Residential Service
Sec. 13.02.071 Approved containers; items placed outside container
(a) The city shall provide a garbage container to each residential customer or business that does not use the
dumpster service. The container shall remain the property of the city and shall not be removed from the
property when changing residences. An identifying number assigns containers to the property address. All
household garbage shall be placed for collection in plastic bags. Bags shall be securely [tied] and placed in
containers provided by the city.
(b) Customers are required to place containers to the curb on collection day no later than 7:00 a.m. and
retrieved from the curb no later than 7:00 p.m. the same day.
(c) Approved plastic bags may be purchased at city hall by residents of the city. There shall be no loose
garbage in cans.
(d) Unauthorized containers will not be serviced.
(e) Bags placed outside carts will not be collected. Exceptions to this provision will be made during the
Christmas holiday. Work orders must be placed for items outside the carts by calling the solid waste
department. Containers should not be overfilled so that lids on the containers do not close properly.
(f) If a container is overfilled, the customer is responsible for debris that falls onto the ground. Drivers are not
responsible for debris that falls onto the ground unless the container is knocked over by the driver.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-11; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.20; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)

Sec. 13.02.072 Collection schedule
(a) The city shall collect refuse from residential and small commercial customers not using the dumpster
services once per week.
(b) City containers should be placed for collection by 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection, and removed by 7:00
p.m. the same day.
(c) Excess garbage accumulated during the Christmas holiday should be bagged and placed at the curb
three feet from the container.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-12; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.21; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.073 Placement of containers at curb or edge or roadway
(a) City containers shall be placed for collection at the curbside of the street in front of the property, so as to
be readily accessible to city solid waste vehicles.
(b) Where no curb is available, containers shall be placed so as to be easily visible and not more than three
feet from the edge of the roadway or other structures. Containers are not to be placed in ditch lines and must
be on the roadway side of ditches.
(1995 Code, sec. 50.22(A), (B); Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.074 Hazardous materials prohibited
It shall be considered an offense for flammable, toxic, corrosive or otherwise hazardous liquids and materials to
be placed for collection. (1995 Code, sec. 50.22(C); Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.075 Replacement of container
If the assigned container is lost by theft, the customer must contact the police department to acquire a case
number. After the case number is issued, a replacement cart will be distributed. If a cart is damaged due to
unavoidable circumstances, the city will replace the container at no cost to the occupant. If the container is
damaged beyond use as a result of the occupant's neglect or misuse, a fee to cover all costs for the
replacement of the container will be charged by the city. (1995 Code, sec. 50.22(D); Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.076 Junk and landscape waste
(a) Junk will be collected by special pickup. Arrangements for this service can be made by contacting the
city's solid waste or public works department.
(b) Bagged leaves, lawn clippings, and straw shall be one time per week.
(c) Any brush trimmings, limbs, or pruning of trees or vegetation by occupants, tenants or owners may be
collected along with leaves, lawn clippings and straw as long as such trimmings are no larger than 24 inches in
diameter, no longer than six feet, and are tied in bundles weighing no more than 40 pounds.
(d) Limbs and brush not in compliance with the above provisions shall be collected on a per-case basis by
work order called into the solid waste services department.
(e) It shall be considered an offense for flammable, toxic, corrosive or otherwise hazardous liquids and
materials to be placed for collection.
(f) The city is not responsible for the collection of contracted or commercial landscape debris. This material
shall be brought to the recycling center at the owner's or contractor's expense, or otherwise properly disposed
of. (See section 13.02.197, pertaining to landscape waste collection.)
(1972 Code, sec. 13-13; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.23; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)

Sec. 13.02.111 Dumpster fees; maintenance
(a) Dumpsters to be provided by city. Commercial dumpsters will be provided by the city's solid waste
department.
(b) Fees. Fees shall be as set forth in the fee schedule.
(c) Collection rates. Rates for servicing the containers shall be per cubic yard, and shall be covered by
division 2 of this article.
(d) Maintenance and repair. The solid waste department will maintain and repair dumpsters under normal
conditions. Charges for repairs made due to deliberate abuse of the container by the customer will be the
responsibility of the customer, and charges will be based on the actual cost of repair.

Sec. 13.02.112 Site for container; enclosure
(a) Customers shall provide a site for their container that is readily accessible by collection vehicles on the
establishment's property. Maintenance of this site, together with the approach, shall be the responsibility of the
owner. The city will not be responsible for damage to drives, parking lots, or other sites.
(b) Refuse containers shall not block roads or street rights-of-way, drainage ditches, or traffic or sight
triangles at intersections.
(c) Overhead clearance of the refuse container area shall be as necessary to facilitate dumping.
(d) All new commercial facilities that require dumpsters must provide a three-sided enclosed area for the
dumpster, as per the city standard, exhibit A attached to Ordinance 3795.
(e) Dumpster enclosures shall be sized with dimensions per exhibit A attached to Ordinance 3795.
(f) New businesses moving into existing buildings with dumpster enclosures are required to bring enclosures
up to departmental specifications.
(g) Enclosures with gates must have gate stops to secure open gates. Claims for damages to any enclosures
caused by the solid waste services department will not be considered unless enclosures are built to
departmental specifications.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-21; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.31; Ordinance 3795 adopted

Sec. 13.02.113 Placement of waste in container
It shall be the owner's or occupant's duty to place all refuse inside containers. There should be no accumulation
on top of lids or around containers. Lids and doors should be kept closed at all times except when being filled.
Nothing should be placed in containers that would extend from any opening. (1972 Code, sec. 13-22;
Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.32; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.114 Items prohibited in dumpsters
(a) It shall be considered an offense for any item to be placed in dumpsters that, because of size, weight, or
any other physical property, could cause damage to the collection vehicle. These items include, but are not
limited to, any one item over three feet in any dimension, any one item in excess of 50 pounds, any concrete,
bricks, dirt, blocks, or other earthen material, boards (over three feet long), pallets, timbers, and the like. These
items shall be placed in a roll-off container for disposal.
(b) Tires will not be accepted. If tires are collected undetected, the customer will be charged as provided in
the fee schedule.
(c) Persons, businesses, or other entities placing such items in containers for collection will be required to
remove these items before collection can take place.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-23; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.33; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.02.115 Refusal of service
If any of the regulations and provisions contained herein is not adhered to, the city retains the right to refuse
service to that container and/or customer. (1972 Code, sec. 13-24; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995
Code, sec. 50.34; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.116 Roll-off containers
(a) The city will provide service of roll-off containers at the rate prescribed herein. Customers may provide a
container that is compatible with the city roll-off collection vehicles. These containers will be maintained by the
owner to adequately insure the safety of the city, its personnel and equipment, and the public.
(b) These containers should only be loaded to the point that they can be tarped and hauled without loss of
refuse along roadways.
(c) Compactor type roll-off containers should be serviced often enough to insure that their weight does not
cause damage to the city's equipment or create unsafe hauling conditions. Compactors that require special
handling will be charged for five yards extra.
(d) If any of these conditions exist or persist, the city could suggest alternatives or refuse service until the
situation is corrected.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-25; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 50.35; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.117 Rental properties and apartment complexes
All rental properties and apartment complexes are considered commercial businesses. Any junk items placed
out for collection must have a work order. The property owner or the complex manager must call in all work
orders. Such businesses will receive one free pickup per year. All work orders after that will be accompanied by
a service charge as provided in the fee schedule. Businesses shall provide a site readily accessible by
collection vehicles. (1995 Code, sec. 50.36; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005; Ordinance adopting Code)

Sec. 13.02.151 Penalty

Any business that violates any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of violating an ordinance

Sec. 13.02.153 Collection schedule; placement for collection
Downtown businesses shall have two garbage pickups per week and one recycling pickup per week. Regular
trash is collected each Tuesday and Friday afternoon. Recyclables will be collected on Thursdays only. All

Sec. 13.02.155 Cart service

Sec. 13.02.156 Dumpster service

Sec. 13.02.158 Rates and charges
Downtown businesses using the cart and bag service will be charged a flat rate as set forth in the fee schedule
on their utility bill. Businesses using the dumpster service are required to purchase a dumpster and pay a
monthly collection fee. (See section 13.02.041 for a listing of these fees.) (1995 Code, sec. 55.07; Ordinance
3795 adopted 9/20/2005; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.02.159 Businesses with multiple tenants
Multi-unit tenants shall be charged on a per-unit basis. Each tenant shall be charged a flat rate as provided in

Sec. 13.02.160 Household garbage prohibited
Under no circumstances shall downtown merchants place household garbage at curbside, in carts, or in
dumpsters serviced by the city's solid waste services department. This provision also applies to litter containers
provided for pedestrian traffic. Violations of these provisions will be subject to a penalty under section
13.02.151. (1995 Code, sec. 55.09; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)

Division 6. Recycling
Sec. 13.02.191 Penalty
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of violating an
ordinance governing public health and sanitation, which is a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof in the
municipal court of the city shall be punished by a fine up to the maximum amount of $2,000.00 for each offense,
with each and every day being a separate offense. (1995 Code, sec. 54.99; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.192 Passage for collection vehicles
The director shall be responsible for the safe passage of collection vehicles through the city roads and
alleyways, to include tree trimming and brush removal as necessary. (1995 Code, sec. 54.01; Ordinance 3795
adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.193 Collection to be provided by city; collection schedule
(a) The city shall provide residential and commercial recycling collection within the city limits, and no person
shall engage in the business of collecting and selling of residential or commercial materials placed out for
collection.
(b) Curbside recycling collection shall be once per week. Commercial recycling collection shall be placed on
a routine schedule based on frequency of collection and size of dumpster. The director has the authority to
revise the residential or commercial collection schedule as deemed necessary for holidays or other compelling
reasons.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.02; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.194 General regulations; containers
(a) The city shall provide residential and commercial customers a specified recycling container for the
collection of recyclable materials. Containers will be distributed by the city at no cost to the customer. The
container shall remain the property of the city and shall not be removed from the property when changing
residences. Containers are assigned to the property address by an identifying number.
(b) If the assigned container is lost by theft, the customer must contact the police department to acquire a
case number. After the case number is issued, a replacement cart will be distributed. If a cart is damaged due
to unavoidable circumstances, the city will replace the container at no cost to the occupant. If the container is
damaged beyond use as a result of the occupant's neglect or misuse, a fee to cover all costs for the
replacement of the container will be charged to the customer.
(c) The occupant shall promptly notify the solid waste department in the event of the need for repair or
replacement of the container.
(d) Residential recycling containers set out for collection should be placed within three feet of the easement
area, with the handles facing the house. When storing the container or when the container has been set out for
collection, the lid must be kept closed at all times to prevent any accumulation of water. Overfilling the container
is not permissible, and no items should be placed on top of the lid or on the ground beside the container; this
hinders the collection process.
(e) Recyclable material must be placed directly inside the recycling container and not bagged, allowing
processing of the material to be simplified.
(f) The customer is required to place the container to the curb no later than 7:00 a.m. on collection day, and
remove from the curb no later than 7:00 p.m. on the same day.
(g) Residential customers are restricted from putting construction debris, hot ashes, oil, corrosive solvents,
pool chemicals, car batteries or other hazardous substances in the residential recycling container.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 380/590
(h) Any container more than 200 pounds will not be serviced.
(i) The city will not service any material placed outside the container unless a work order is placed with solid
waste services for a separate pickup.
(j) If a residence or commercial customer serviced regularly by the city generates more recyclable material
than can be placed in the recycling container for the once-a-week collection, the customer may request a
second blue cart at no additional charge.
(k) The customer shall not mark or deface the recyclable container in any way and shall be responsible for
maintaining the cleanliness of the container.
(l) No person other than the current resident of the property obtaining such container, a city collector or an
authorized city employee shall remove, pick up or transfer materials which have been placed in a city-owned
container at any residence or business. Each violation of this provision which occurs from one or more
collection locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense, punishable as provided in section
13.02.191.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.03; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.195 Commercial service
(a) For each commercial customer that participates in the city's recycling program efforts, the city will furnish,
at no cost to the customer for the container, a four-yard or eight-yard container(s) for this purpose. It is the
desire of the city to establish a regular, routine weekly routing schedule for pickup of the recycled waste in order
to achieve the greatest cost savings. Therefore, rates for regular, routine weekly pickups are as provided in the
fee schedule.
(b) Small businesses that do not require a dumpster for recycling collection have the option of using the 65-
gallon blue curbside containers at no cost. Only three blue containers are allowed per business.
(c) Collection of all materials is contingent on compliance with regulations.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-8; 1995 Code, sec. 54.04; Ordinance 3208 adopted 9/3/1996; Ordinance 3270 adopted
9/2/1997; Ordinance 3342 adopted 9/1/1998; Ordinance 3412 adopted 9/7/1999; Ordinance 3428 adopted
11/2/1999; Ordinance 3485 adopted 9/5/2000; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.02.196 Contamination with unacceptable items; inspection program
(a) All recycling containers are the property of the city. It is the resident's or the business's responsibility to
keep these containers clean and free of contamination.
(b) Inspections are conducted at random on residential customers through the “red tag” program. City
employees will randomly select a particular route to inspect. Inspectors will be looking inside the blue curbside
containers for contaminates that will spoil recyclables, such as food, diapers, household trash or any other item
that is not acceptable inside the blue curbside container. If contamination exists, the container will be red
tagged and will not be emptied. After a customer has been “red tagged” three times, their cart will be picked up
and after 30 days the customer may request it back after signing an agreement with the recycling coordinator.
Businesses who have dumpsters may also be “red tagged” for contamination. If a dumpster contains any item
except recyclable materials, the city has the authority to deny service to that dumpster. The customer will be
asked to either remove the contamination to allow the dumpster to be emptied, or pay a service charge as
provided in the fee schedule to have the dumpster emptied by the city's garbage collection service.
(c) It is understandable that residents or businesses that make an effort to recycle correctly may sometimes
make a mistake and place unacceptable items in with their recyclables. In this case, during the inspection
process, the containers will be given a tag to remind the resident to be more careful when placing items in the
blue containers. The containers will be emptied as long as the contamination is not too severe.
(d) The purpose of the inspection process is to help educate citizens and to decrease the contamination rate.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.05; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005; Ordinance adopting Code)
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 381/590
Sec. 13.02.197 Landscape waste collection
(a) The city will promote and encourage citizens to allow grass clippings to remain on their yard, eliminating
the collection and landfilling of bags of grass. The city will also encourage the citizens, when feasible, to
prepare their own composting areas.
(b) In the instances where the citizens cannot feasibly allow the clippings to remain on their lawns, the
clippings can be accumulated and put out for collection in bags which have been approved by the city.
(c) All bags must be tied and must not be overfilled. A filled bag must weigh no more than 50 pounds. There
shall be no contents other than grass, leaves, limbs and other such items designated as landscape waste
placed in the bags. Failure to follow these basic guidelines will result in non-collection of landscape waste.
(d) Bagged yard waste shall be collected once a week through a route system. Bags should be placed at the
curb for collection. Residents may contact the solid waste services department for specific collection days.
(e) Tree trimmings, brush and shrubs shall be placed in manageable piles of no more than six feet in length
and no more than 40 pounds in weight, at the curb. The customer should contact the recycling or solid waste
department to place a work order, then allow up to five business days for collection.
(f) Wooden fence material is acceptable if sections are no longer than four feet by six feet and hinges,
latches, and bolts have been removed. No painted or stained wood can be accepted.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.06; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.198 Regional recycling center
(a) A drop-off site at the regional recycling center, located at 500 Southpark Drive, is available 24 hours a
day, 7 days a week. This facility is open to the entire Deep East Texas region. Items accepted at the drop-off
site must be sorted according to material. Materials accepted are cardboard, newspapers, office paper,
aluminum cans, steel cans, plastics #1 and #2, telephone books and magazines. This area is under 24-hour
surveillance, and any misuse of the facility, such as illegal dumping, shall be punishable by a fine up to
$500.00.
(b) Other items accepted at the recycling center Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. only
are:
(1) Used motor oil - up to 5 gallons per visit;
(2) Oil filters; and
(3) Car and small engine batteries - up to 5 per visit.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.07; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.199 Special collection events
To promote recycling and proper solid waste management, the city will work to organize special community
collection events. Current and future collection events include:
(1) Tire reclamation day;
(2) Christmas card recycling;
(3) Christmas tree recycling;
(4) Household hazardous waste collection;
(5) Electronics collection; and
(6) Telephone book recycling.
(1995 Code, sec. 54.08; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 382/590
Sec. 13.02.200 Unauthorized removal of recyclable material
No person other than the current resident of the property containing a collection location, a city collector, or an
authorized recycling contractor shall remove, pick up, or transfer recyclable materials which have been placed
in a recycling container in any residential subdivision, or at any single-family dwelling. Each violation of this
provision which occurs from one or more collection locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense
punishable as provided in section 13.02.191. (1995 Code, sec. 54.09; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.201 Ownership of recyclable material
Recyclable materials placed in a residential recycling container, or adjacent to a commercial recycling
container, for collection by a city collector, become the property of the city. An owner or contractor may recycle
materials as a result of construction or demolition. (1995 Code, sec. 54.10; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Secs. 13.02.202–13.02.230 Reserved
Division 7. Special Waste
Part I. In General
Sec. 13.02.231 Definitions
For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
Special waste. Any commercial or residential garbage, trash, rubbish, hazardous waste, infectious waste, or
other solid waste that because of its quantity, concentration, physical or chemical characteristics or biological
properties is not collectable by the city's solid waste department.
(1995 Code, sec. 53.01; Ordinance 3214 adopted 10/15/1996; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.232 Penalty
Any person violating any provision of this division shall, upon conviction, be fined in a sum not exceeding
$2,000.00. Each day that a provision of this division is violated shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(1995 Code, sec. 53.99; Ordinance 3214 adopted 10/15/1996; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.233 Collection and disposal generally
(a) The director of the city's solid waste services department shall keep a list of special waste that is not
acceptable for collection and disposal by the solid waste services department. The head of the solid waste
department may also make rules regarding the collection and disposal by the city's sanitation division of any
garbage, rubbish, trash or other solid waste that requires special preparation or handling to meet the
requirements of any state or federal law regulation, which are otherwise necessary to safely and properly
collect, transport and provide for disposal. The list of special waste and the rules shall be written and kept on
file by the head of the solid waste services department and be available for public inspection during regular
business hours.
(b) No person shall deposit any special waste in any container serviced by the city's solid waste services
department. The city solid waste department may refuse to collect, transport or dispose of special waste that
does not comply with this division.
(c) The property owner shall be responsible for arranging with a state commission on environmental quality
authorized private hauler for the collection, removal and disposal of any special waste that the city's solid waste
services department will not collect.
(1995 Code, sec. 53.02; Ordinance 3214 adopted 10/15/1996; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.234 Arrangements for collection

3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.235 Hauler's permit
(a) No person shall collect or remove for compensation from any property within the city any special waste
without first obtaining a special waste hauler's permit from the division of solid waste.
(b) Each year, property owners or private special waste haulers are required to provide proof of state
commission on environmental quality authorization to the director of the solid waste services department.
(1995 Code, sec. 53.04; Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.236 Collection by private haulers restricted
Beginning November 20, 1996, the city's solid waste department shall be the exclusive provider of residential
and commercial garbage, rubbish, recyclable refuse or other collection and disposal services for all premises,
and it shall be unlawful for any other person to provide residential or commercial garbage, rubbish, recyclable
refuse or other collection or disposal services to any person for compensation after November 20, 1996, except
as otherwise permitted by this division. (1995 Code, sec. 53.05; Ordinance 3214 adopted 10/15/1996;
Ordinance 3795 adopted 9/20/2005)
Secs. 13.02.237–13.02.260 Reserved
Part II. Waste From Health Care Related Facilities
Sec. 13.02.261 Definitions
For the purpose of this part, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires
a different meaning:
Animal waste.
(1) Carcasses of animals intentionally exposed to pathogens;
(2) Body parts of animals intentionally exposed to pathogens;
(3) Whole bulk blood and blood products, serum, and other blood components from animals
intentionally exposed to pathogens; and
(4) Bedding of animals intentionally exposed to pathogens.
Blood and blood products. All waste bulk human blood, serum, plasma and other blood components.
Bulk blood or body fluids. A volume of 100 milliliters or more.
Microbiological waste.
(1) Cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals;
(2) Cultures of specimens from medical, pathological, pharmaceutical, research, clinical,
commercial and industrial laboratories;
(3) Discarded live and attenuated vaccines;
(4) Disposable culture dishes; and
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 384/590
(5) Disposable devices used to transfer, inoculate and mix cultures.
Pathological waste.
(1) Human materials removed during surgery, labor and delivery, autopsy, or biopsy, including:
(A) Body parts;
(B) Tissues or fetuses;
(C) Organs; and
(D) Bulk blood and body fluids;
(2) Products of spontaneous human abortions, including body parts, tissue, fetuses, organs, and
bulk blood and body fluids, regardless of the period of gestation;
(3) Laboratory specimens of blood and tissue after completion of laboratory examination; and
(4) Anatomical remains.
Sharps. Shall include the following materials when contaminated:
(1) Hypodermic needles;
(2) Hypodermic syringes with attached needles;
(3) Scalpel blades;
(4) Razor blades and disposable razors used in surgery, labor and delivery, or other medical
procedures;
(5) Pasteur pipettes; and
(6) Broken glass laboratories.
Special waste from health care related facilities. A solid waste which, if improperly treated or handled, may
serve to transmit an infectious disease, and which is comprised of the following:
(1) Animal waste;
(2) Bulk blood and blood products;
(3) Microbiological waste;
(4) Pathological waste; and
(5) Sharps.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-30; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 53.20; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.262 Applicability; exceptions
(a) This part does not apply to waste generated by the operation of:
(1) Single- or multi-family dwellings; and
(2) Hotels, motels, or other accommodations which provide lodging and other service for the
public.
(b) This part does not apply to:
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 385/590
(1) Teeth;
(2) Human tissue, including fetal tissue, donated for research or teaching purposes, with the
consent of the person authorized to consent as otherwise provided by law, to an institution of higher
learning, medical school, a teaching hospital affiliated with a medical school, or a research institution
or individual investigator subject to the jurisdiction of an institutional review board required by 42
USC 289; and
(3) Placentas designated for sale and obtained from a licensed hospital or a licensed birthing
center.
(c) This part does apply to special waste from health care related facilities generated by the operation of the
following publicly or privately owned or operated health care related facilities, including, but not limited to:
(1) Ambulatory surgical centers;
(2) Abortion clinics;
(3) Birthing centers;
(4) Blood banks and blood drawing centers;
(5) Clinics, including but not limited to medical, dental, and veterinary;
(6) Clinical, diagnostic, pathological or biomedical research laboratories;
(7) Educational institution health centers;
(8) Educational institution research laboratories;
(9) Emergency medical service providers;
(10) End stage renal dialysis facilities;
(11) Funeral establishments;
(12) Home health agencies;
(13) Hospitals;
(14) Long-term care facilities;
(15) Mental health and mental retardation facilities, including but not limited to hospitals, schools,
and community centers;
(16) Minor emergency centers;
(17) Occupational health clinics and clinical laboratories;
(18) Pharmacies;
(19) Pharmaceutical manufacturing plants and research laboratories;
(20) Professional offices, including but not limited to the offices of physicians and dentists;
(21) Special residential care facilities; and
(22) Veterinary clinical and research laboratories.
(1972 Code, sec. 13-31; Ordinance 2933 adopted 2/16/1993; 1995 Code, sec. 53.21; Ordinance 3795 adopted
9/20/2005)
Sec. 13.02.263 Disposal through city collection service prohibited

(a) A person commits an offense if that person disposes of special waste from a health care related facility by

(b) A person commits an offense if that person disposes of special waste from a health care related facility by

ARTICLE 13.03 WATER SERVICE*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.03.001 Penalty
Users of the city water, except for the city, who do not comply with this article shall be subject to a penalty and
fine of not more than $500.00 per day for each day of noncompliance and/or disconnection or discontinuance of
water services to such users by the city. (1972 Code, sec. 26-4(d); 1995 Code, sec. 52.99(A))
Sec. 13.03.002 Consent to creation of Central Water Control and Improvement District
The city consents to the creation of the Central Water Control and Improvement District, a waiver of any claim it
may have to object to the creation of the water control and improvement district and/or the improvements that
are contemplated and/or the issuance of the revenue notes by the Central Water Control and Improvement
District. (1995 Code, sec. 52.75; Resolution 3563 adopted 3/5/2002)
Secs. 13.03.003–13.03.040 Reserved
Division 2. Rates, Charges and Billing
Sec. 13.03.041 Connection fees; installation of connection
(a) Water connection fees. Water connection fees shall be as provided in the fee schedule. In new
subdivisions where the developer installs water service lines to the property line in all lots within the subdivision,
the connection fee for a three-quarter-inch water service line shall be reduced by $40.00.
(b) Installation of connection. The city water and sewer department will make all water connections to the city
main line outside and inside the city limits.
(1972 Code, sec. 26-2(a)(c); Ordinance 1358 adopted 1/21/1969; Ordinance 1536 adopted 8/8/1972;
Ordinance 2672 adopted 5/3/1988; Ordinance 3000 adopted 1/18/1994; 1995 Code, sec. 52.01; Ordinance
3271 adopted 9/2/1997; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.03.042 Deposits; minimum rates
(a) The charges provided in the fee schedule are established as water meter deposits for water meters used
for city water service. Churches, Lufkin Independent School District, county offices and irrigation meters are
exempt from water meter deposits. Meter deposits for industrial customers are assessed by individual
agreement with the city.
(b) Water meter deposits of those customers that have demonstrated good pay records, will have their
deposits credited to their accounts, without interest, after twelve months. A good pay record is defined as
having made twelve consecutive timely payments with no cutoffs and no late fees. The city may accept a
current (no more than one month old) letter of credit from another water utility or municipality in lieu of requiring
a water meter deposit. The city may also accept the co-signature of a current city water customer with a good
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 387/590
payment record in lieu of a deposit, provided the cosigner executes an agreement with the city for “co-signature
in lieu of deposit.”
(c) Each family unit served by one water meter shall pay the minimum rate for water inside the city limits and
at one and one-half times the rate outside the city limits.
(1972 Code, sec. 26-3; Ordinance 2101 adopted 3/17/1981; Ordinance 2852 adopted 9/17/1991; Ordinance
2900 adopted 9/1/1992; Ordinance 3065 adopted 10/4/1994; 1995 Code, sec. 52.02; Ordinance 3131 adopted
9/5/1995; Ordinance 3210 adopted 9/17/1996; Ordinance 3545 adopted 10/2/2001; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.03.043 Theft of service; tampering fee and related fees
(a) The utility collections department shall charge a water customer a tampering fee as provided in the fee
schedule plus any charges for the meter and/or necessary components for the first occurrence of any of the
following incidents:
(1) Broken meter lock;
(2) Damaged meter (any means other than natural uncontrollable incidents);
(3) Unauthorized connection inserted (jumper);
(4) Stolen meter placed for connection;
(5) Use of city cut-off causing damage which is repaired by the city;
(6) Use of city cut-off to reconnect water service after city disconnects service.
(b) In the event of repeated violations regarding theft of service, the city will take the necessary steps to
prevent water service from being accessed at that location. The city will plug the main line to prevent further
customer usage and charge the customer a fee as provided in the fee schedule. All expenses related to the
prevention of accessing water because of tampering will be charged to the person who is receiving the
economic benefit of the service.
(c) Stolen meter/jumper is placed for connection. If the customer is not an account holder with the city at the
location in question, then the account will be charged a flat consumption of 10,000 gallons for each month the
meter was suspected to have been in the ground. Confirmation will be attained by contacting the other utility
companies and verifying the date of service.
(d) The utility collections department shall charge a water customer as provided in the fee schedule for
removing a water meter due to discontinuance of water service for nonpayment of the bill.
(e) Criminal charges related to theft of water utility service may also be filed dependent upon the
circumstances and the severity of the offense under Tex. Penal Code section 28.03(a)–(f).
(1995 Code, sec. 52.03; Ordinance 4162 adopted 9/15/2009; Ordinance 4274 adopted 9/21/2010; Ordinance
4381 adopted 9/20/2011; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.03.044 Rate schedule
Water rates shall be as provided in the fee schedule. (Ordinance adopting Code)

on the tenth day after the billing date. If not paid within ten days after the billing date, service shall be subject to
disconnection. In the event the account becomes processed for cutoff because of delinquency, a charge as
provided in the fee schedule shall be assessed.
(b) For each utility account holder 65 years of age and older, a charge as provided in the fee schedule shall
be assessed for reconnection of utility service. Verification of customer's age shall be required; acceptable proof

ARTICLE 13.04 SEWER SERVICE*
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 13.04.001–13.04.040 Reserved
Division 2. Rates and Charges
Sec. 13.04.041 Connection fee
Connection fees shall be in the amount established in the fee schedule. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.04.042 Rate schedule
(a) Residential and multi-unit sewer rates.
(1) Residential sewer customers shall be charged for sewer service based on their winter billing
months' average water consumption. For purposes of computing sewer rates, winter billing months
are defined as December, January and February. Sewer customers who have not established their
winter billing months' average will be billed based on actual water consumption or 20,000 gallons,
whichever is less, until their winter billing months' average water consumption is established. The
maximum sewer billing for residential sewer service shall not exceed 20,000 gallons of water
consumption per month.
(2) Multi-unit dwellings shall be charged on a per-unit basis by dividing the total water use on the
master meter by the number of units in the dwelling. This average consumption per unit will be used
to calculate the wastewater user charge for each unit. Then the average charge per unit, times the
number of units, equals the total user charge for that meter.
(3) Monthly residential and multi-unit sewer rates are as provided in the fee schedule.
(b) Commercial sewer rates. General commercial sewer customers shall be charged for sewer service based
on their actual monthly water consumption and number of units serviced. There is no maximum billing. Monthly
commercial sewer rates are as provided in the fee schedule.
(c) Industrial sewer rates. Industrial sewer customers are those sewer customers meeting the requirements
of the United States Environmental Protection Agency Pretreatment Program and article 13.05 of this chapter.
These customers shall be charged for actual monthly effluent loadings (BOD and TSS) based on specific
predetermined effluent sampling programs administered by the city's wastewater treatment department.
Industrial rates shall be determined by the formula provided in the fee schedule.
(d) Rates outside city limits; rates outside extraterritorial limits.
(1) Outside the city limits, the rate shall be equivalent to two times that rate inside the city limits.
(2) Outside the city's extraterritorial limits, the rate shall be equivalent to two and one-half times
that rate inside the city limits.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 389/590
(1995 Code, sec. 51.111; Ordinance 3132 adopted 9/5/1995; Ordinance 3207 adopted 9/3/1996; Ordinance
3341 adopted 9/1/1998; Ordinance 3411 adopted 9/7/1999; Ordinance 3484 adopted 9/5/2000; Ordinance 3591
adopted 9/3/2002; Ordinance 3608 adopted 1/21/2003; Ordinance 3655 adopted 9/16/2003; Ordinance 3714
adopted 9/7/2004; Ordinance 3783 adopted 8/16/2005; Ordinance 3902 adopted 9/5/2006; Ordinance 4006
adopted 9/4/2007; Ordinance 4163 adopted 9/15/2009; Ordinance 4272 adopted 9/21/2010; Ordinance 4380
adopted 9/20/2011; Ordinance adopting Code)
Secs. 13.04.043–13.04.070 Reserved
Division 3. Sewer Use and Construction Standards
Sec. 13.04.071 Definitions
Unless the context specifically and clearly indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms and phrases used in this
division shall be as follows:
Building sewer. The extension from the sanitary sewer drainage system of any structure to the public sewer
mains.
Building sewer connection. The pipe installed from the property line to the building to receive the sanitary
sewage generated by a building or household.
City. The City of Lufkin, acting by and through its council members or, in appropriate cases, acting by and
through its authorized representatives.
Natural outlet. Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water.
Notice. Actual notice or written notice mailed postage prepaid first class mail to any person's last known
address.
Owner. Any person vested with ownership, legal or equitable, sole or partial, or possession of any improved
property.
Person. Any individual, partnership, company, association, society, corporation, or other legal entity.
Sanitary sewage. Normal water-carried household and toilet wastes discharged from any improved property,
excluding ground, surface, or storm water.
Sewer. Any pipe or conduit constituting a part of the sewer collection system used or usable for sewage
collection purposes.
Sewer collection system. All facilities, as of any particular time, for collecting, pumping, and transporting and
treating sanitary sewage located in the city limits and/or owned and maintained and operated by the city.
Sewer stub. That portion of the sewer that connects to the public sewer main and extends to the property line
and is available to receive a building sewer connection.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.170; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
Sec. 13.04.072 Violations; penalty; damaging or tampering with wastewater system
(a) Any person violating any provision of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Thirty days following
notice to the owner of such violation, each day of continued violation shall be a separate offense. This penalty
shall be in addition to the city's right to correct or enjoin any violation, charging the expense thereof to the
owner.
(b) Any person found to be violating any provision of this division shall be served by the city with written
notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correcting
thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The
city may, after informal notice to the person discharging wastewater to the public sewer, immediately halt or
prevent such discharge reasonably appearing to present an imminent endangerment to the environment, or
which threatens to interfere with the operation of the public sewer or wastewater treatment facilities.
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 390/590
(c) Any person found to be violating any provisions of this division shall be fined in the amount not exceeding
$500.00 for each violation in the case of an individual, and $1,000.00 for each violation in the case of a
corporation or unincorporated association. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed
a separate offense.
(d) No person shall break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is part of the wastewater facilities. Any person violating this provision shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.999(D); Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
Sec. 13.04.073 Use of public sewers required; extension of service
(a) The owner of a building or any part of a building occupied as a residential, commercial, or manufacturing
facility located within 100 feet of a public sewer shall connect such building with the sewer in such manner as
the city may require within 90 days after notice to such owner from the city to make such connection, for the
purpose of discharging all sanitary sewer and industrial waste from such buildings into the public sewer, subject
to any limitations and restrictions as are established in this division and/or any other regulation or the city's
industrial pretreatment program. Each such owner shall, at the same time limit, cease and desist from all further
discharge of sanitary sewage or industrial waste, except into the public sewer.
(b) The city shall extend the public sewer at its expense to provide a sewer stub for a building or proposed
building located on a lot of record if such building or proposed building is located within the city limits. The
timing and location of the extension of service shall be determined by the city based on budgetary constraints. It
is the policy of the city that no sewer service shall be provided to a person outside the city limits. The city
council may, on a case-by-case basis, extend sewer service to nonprofit corporations outside the city limits
which are located within 100 feet of the sewer collection system.
(c) All sanitary sewage and industrial wastes from any building, after connection of such building with a sewer
as required under subsection (a), shall be conducted into a sewer, subject to limitations and restrictions as shall
be established herein or otherwise shall be established by the city from time to time.
(d) (1) It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any
unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of
the city, any human or other objectionable waste.
(2) It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has
been provided in accordance with the provisions of this division and the state.
(e) No privy vault, cesspool, sinkhole, septic tank, on-site sewer system or similar receptacle shall be used
and maintained at any time for any building which has been connected to a sewer or which shall be required
under subsection (a) to be connected to a sewer.
(f) No privy vault, cesspool, sinkhole, septic tank, on-site sewer system, or similar receptacle at any time
shall be connected with a sewer.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.171; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
Sec. 13.04.074 Standards for building sewer and connection
(a) Except as otherwise provided in this section, each building shall be connected separately and
independently with a sewer through a building sewer. Grouping of more than one single-family dwelling on a
sewer stub shall not be permitted, except under special circumstances and for good sanitary reasons or other
good cause shown, but then only after special permission of the city engineer, in writing, shall have been
secured and subject to such rules, regulations, and conditions as may be prescribed by the city.
(b) The city will, at its expense, during construction of a new sewer, construct a sewer stub from the public
sewer to the property line of each existing lot along the line, and all costs and expenses of construction of the
remainder of the building sewer, including connection to the structures served, shall be borne by the owner of
the building to be connected, and such owner shall indemnify and save harmless the city, its officers and agents
from all loss or damage that may be occasioned, directly or indirectly, as a result of construction of a building
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 391/590
sewer connection on the owner's premises or the connection to the sewer system. After the initial construction
of the building sewer connection, the owner shall thereafter be obligated to pay all costs of expenses of
operation, repair, and maintenance and of reconstruction of the entire building sewer beginning at the public
sewer main and ending at the building.
(c) A building sewer shall be connected to the public sewer main at the place designated by the city and
where a connection is provided.
(d) If the owner of any building located within the city and benefitted, improved, served or accommodated by
any sewer, or to which any sewer is available, after 90 days' notice from the city in accordance with section
13.04.073(a), shall fail to connect such building as required, he or she shall be in violation of this division and
the city may make such connection and may collect from such owner the costs and expenses thereof by such
legal proceedings as may be permitted by law. The city shall have full authority to enter on the owner's property
to do whatever is necessary to properly drain sewer from the improved property into the public sewer. Failure to
comply may also result in discontinuing of water service by the city until such time as the property is in
compliance.
(e) No person shall uncover, connect with, make any opening into or use, alter or disturb in any manner any
sewer or any part of the sewer system. All taps, connects, extensions, or any alteration of the sewer system
must be completed by the city's public utilities employees or by contractors employed and supervised by the
city.
(f) The city engineer may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine
compliance with this chapter. These requirements may include:
(1) Wastewater discharge peak rates and volume over a specified time period;
(2) Chemical analyses of wastewaters;
(3) Information on raw materials, processes, and product affecting wastewater volume and quality;
(4) Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent, or other materials important to
sewer use control;
(5) A plot plan of sewers on the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility locations
as prepared by a registered professional engineer or land surveyor;
(6) Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities;
(7) Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal
sewer.
(g) Construction must meet the following requirements:
(1) All connections and joints will be smooth, neat, and watertight;
(2) All pipe materials shall be PVC, ASTM D-3034, SDR 26 or better as approved by the city
engineer. Sewer stubs may use ASTM D-3034, or SDR-35 for sewers less than five feet in depth.
The building sewer connection shall comply with the adopted plumbing code;
(3) All taps, laterals, and connections six inches and greater must be made at a manhole;
(4) All construction must be in accordance with the construction details as identified in section
13.04.079;
(5) All building sewers shall be of sufficient size and type as determined by the city's adopted
building and plumbing codes;
(6) The slope from the building to the public sewer main shall be satisfactory to the director of
building inspections. If the slope cannot be made satisfactory, then such other reasonable steps will
be taken as will be satisfactory to the director of building inspections, up to and including on-site
pumping systems. Any pumping systems will be purchased, maintained and operated by the owner;
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 392/590
(7) All work shall be performed in strict conformity to the requirements of the city.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.172; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
Sec. 13.04.075 Installation and maintenance of building sewer and connection
(a) Inspection of building sewer. No building sewer or repair thereto shall be covered until it has been
inspected and approved by the city. If any part of a building sewer is covered before so being inspected and
approved, it shall be uncovered for inspection at the cost and expense of the owner of the building to be
connected to a sewer.
(b) Maintenance of building sewer. Every building sewer shall be maintained in a sanitary and safe operating
condition by the owner. Failure to maintain the building sewer may result in discontinuing of service.
(c) Guarding of excavations. Every excavation for a building sewer shall be guarded adequately with
barricades and lights to protect all persons from damage and injury, except where the excavation presents no
reasonable danger to either the neighbors or the public.
(d) Correction of unsatisfactory conditions. If any person shall fail or refuse, upon receipt of a notice of the
city, in writing, to remedy any unsatisfactory condition with respect to a building sewer within 45 days of receipt
of such notice (except that in a case of dire emergency this time period may be reduced as necessary to protect
the health and safety of the residents of the city), the city may remedy any unsatisfactory condition with respect
to a building sewer and may collect from the owner the costs and expenses thereof by such legal proceedings
as may be provided by law. The city shall have full authority to enter on the owner's property to do whatever is
necessary to remedy the unsatisfactory condition.
(e) Notification of change in discharge. Any person proposing a new discharge into the system or a
substantial change in the volume or character of pollutants that are discharged into the system shall notify the
city engineer at least 60 days prior to the proposed change or connection. Proposed new discharges from
residential or commercial sources involving loading exceeding 50 population equivalents (5,000 gpd) shall
contact the city engineer for approval. Any new industrial discharge, or any alteration in either flow or waste
characteristics in industrial discharge, must obtain the approval of the wastewater treatment plant
superintendent.
(f) Sealing of sewer when building is demolished. When a building is demolished and not immediately
replaced, the owner, having first notified the building inspections department, shall adequately seal off his
building sewer where it connects to the public sewer main.
(g) Filling of septic tank upon connection to sewer. When a building is once connected to the sewer system,
the owner shall promptly clean and fill the prior private septic or aerobic system in a manner satisfactory to the
city.
(h) Excavations on public property. Where the owner excavates within or otherwise disturbs public property,
then the owner shall give the public utilities department prior notice of the proposed action, shall follow all
directions of the director of public utilities and shall promptly and safely and at the owner's expense, complete
the action and restore the public property in a manner satisfactory to the city.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.173; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
Sec. 13.04.076 Prohibited discharges; discharge of unpolluted water
(a) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater,
groundwater, roof runoff, or subsurface drainage to any sanitary sewer.
(b) Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to storm sewers, if available, or to a
natural outlet approved by the city.
(c) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any substance in violation of sections 13.05.031
through 13.05.033.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.174; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 393/590
Sec. 13.04.077 Variances
(a) The city engineer, with the approval of the city manager, may allow reasonable variances which will not
result in a violation of state or federal law, upon suitable conditions, from this division, provided:
(1) The owner pays a variance fee as provided in the fee schedule. The fee is not refundable
regardless of the outcome of the variance request;
(2) The variance allowed is the least variance reasonable;
(3) The variance will not cause undue harm or inconvenience to the city, the public sewage
system, or the residents of the city;
(4) The variance is justified by substantial reason.
(b) The owner shall apply for the variance in writing to the city engineer. The application shall identify the
name and address of the owner, the property in question, the specific variance sought by the owner and a
substantial reason justifying the variance. The variance fee shall be paid with the application or the variance
shall be deemed to have been denied. The variance, if any, shall identify any changes, limitations or restrictions
on the variance as applied for.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.175; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.04.078 Inspections; right of entry
(a) The director of public utilities and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials
and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation,
measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in accordance with the
provisions of this division.
(b) The director of public utilities and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials
and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly recorded
easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and
maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within said easement.
(1995 Code, sec. 51.176; Ordinance 3599 adopted 10/15/2002)

ARTICLE 13.05 DISCHARGES TO PUBLIC SEWERS*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.05.001 Purpose and policy
(a) This article sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city
and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33
United States Code 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 Code of Federal Regulations
part 403).
(b) The objectives of this article are:
(1) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will
interfere with its operation;
7/15/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 397/590
(2) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will pass
through the publicly owned treatment works, inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or
otherwise be incompatible with the publicly owned treatment works;
(3) To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be affected by wastewater
and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public;
(4) To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from the publicly owned
treatment works:
(5) To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance, and
improvement of the publicly owned treatment Works; and
(6) To enable the city to comply with its Texas Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit
conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the
publicly owned treatment works is subject.
(c) This article shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works. This article authorizes the
issuance of wastewater discharge permits; provides for monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities;
establishes administrative review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for
the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein.
(Ordinance 3064 adopted 9/20/1994; 1995 Code, sec. 51.001; Ordinance 3912 adopted 11/7/2006)
Sec. 13.05.002 Administration
Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions
of this article. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the city manager may be delegated by the city
manager to other city personnel. (Ordinance 3064 adopted 9/20/1994; 1995 Code, sec. 51.002; Ordinance
3912 adopted 11/7/2006)
